question.title: Servlet URL patterns on Google App Engine

node.contents: Sorry, the code is not show well. first must be the servlet declaration as "MyServlet".

astNode.text: Sorry, the code is not show well. first must be the servlet declaration as "MyServlet".

node.contents: I'm trying to do some simple work with url-pattern that works well on localhost but fails when the application is deployed on the GAE server. What I want to do is next:

astNode.text: I'm trying to do some simple work with url-pattern that works well on localhost but fails when the application is deployed on the GAE server. What I want to do is next:

node.contents:
• One servlet to serve all requests
  • This servlet will forward some requests to jsp files (in most cases)

astNode.text:
• One servlet to serve all requests
  • This servlet will forward some requests to jsp files (in most cases)

node.contents: To do this I've configured the web.xml:

astNode.text: To do this I've configured the web.xml:

node.contents: This works fine with the GAE localhost server, but when the app is deployed on the real GAE server, it doesn't. The problem is that when I access to myapp.appspot.com/anything GAE responds:

astNode.text: This works fine with the GAE localhost server, but when the app is deployed on the real GAE server, it doesn't. The problem is that when I access to myapp.appspot.com/anything GAE responds:

node.contents: Error: Not Found The requested URL /anything was not found on this server.

astNode.text: Error: Not Found The requested URL /anything was not found on this server.

node.contents: Thanks Dave. It was a mistake posting the code, but I have the servlet tag already in my web.xml. In fact, it works well in localhost... :(

astNode.text: Thanks Dave. It was a mistake posting the code, but I have the servlet tag already in my web.xml. In fact, it works well in localhost... :(

node.contents: If that is the case, then you should probably update your answer to include your full web.xml, full stack trace (go to `https://appengine.google.com/dashboard?&app_id=s~YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN` where `YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN` is from `YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN.appspot.com` and it should be in the `Errors` section in bottom right).

astNode.text: If that is the case, then you should probably update your answer to include your full web.xml, full stack trace (go to `https://appengine.google.com/dashboard?&app_id=s~YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN` where `YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN` is from `YOUR-APPSPOT-SUBDOMAIN.appspot.com` and it should be in the `Errors` section in bottom right).

node.contents: Also, it might be possible your web xml wasn't uploaded properly. You can verify by adjusting your appengine-web.xml and adding the static-files element as I've described if you haven't already.

astNode.text: Also, it might be possible your web xml wasn't uploaded properly. You can verify by adjusting your appengine-web.xml and adding the static-files element as I've described if you haven't already.

node.contents: Thanks dave. I think that there was a deployment issue, because I've redeployed and now all works fine!

astNode.text: Thanks dave. I think that there was a deployment issue, because I've redeployed and now all works fine!

node.contents: You're missing the Servlet element. The Servlet-mapping element by itself is not sufficient. Building off of your web.xml try this....

astNode.text: You're missing the Servlet element. The Servlet-mapping element by itself is not sufficient. Building off of your web.xml try this....

node.contents: Of course replacing the package.path.to.my.servlet with the actual package of your MyServlet class. Once you've done this you can put in multiple servlet-mapping elements to map different urls to the same servlet.

astNode.text: Of course replacing the package.path.to.my.servlet with the actual package of your MyServlet class. Once you've done this you can put in multiple servlet-mapping elements to map different urls to the same servlet.

node.contents: If this is happening at your appspot url, you can try and make sure all of your static files are being deployed to your appspot...

astNode.text: If this is happening at your appspot url, you can try and make sure all of your static files are being deployed to your appspot...

node.contents: Just note that this means you're deploying all xmls/css files within your war file. Adjust the include path attribute accordingly if you don't want to do this.

astNode.text: Just note that this means you're deploying all xmls/css files within your war file. Adjust the include path attribute accordingly if you don't want to do this.

node.contents: Also, to have all requests go to one servlet, just use the following url pattern...

astNode.text: Also, to have all requests go to one servlet, just use the following url pattern...

node.contents: Just keep in mind when using this pattern that if you have images/css files/jsp files/etc that this servlet will intercept the request for them. So you're going to have some kind of logic that forwards the requests you're not interested in. This might be sufficient if you're doing something straight forward; but as you get more complicated (ex caching css files/image files) you're probably going to want to look into adding a static resource filter.

astNode.text: Just keep in mind when using this pattern that if you have images/css files/jsp files/etc that this servlet will intercept the request for them. So you're going to have some kind of logic that forwards the requests you're not interested in. This might be sufficient if you're doing something straight forward; but as you get more complicated (ex caching css files/image files) you're probably going to want to look into adding a static resource filter.
